title: Watch Claude Code iteratively improve its reference bitnet
description: Hacker News discussion about watching Claude Code improve its reference bitnet implementation live, showcasing the iterative development capabilities of AI coding agents and how they can refine their own code over time.
author: Hacker News community

title: Tell HN: Claude Has Had 57 Incidents in the Past 3 Months
description: Hacker News post noting frequent issues with both web Claude and Claude Code, highlighting reliability concerns and production stability challenges when using AI coding assistants at scale.
author: Hacker News community

title: AI编程的困境: The Dilemma of AI Programming - The Missing Layer Between Business and Code
description: Chinese article discussing the 'missing layer' that connects business requirements with AI-generated code. The piece explores the challenges that arise when AI coding tools like Claude Code generate code that doesn't fully align with business needs, highlighting the gap between technical implementation and business logic. References Hacker News discussions about this emerging problem.
author: Toy's Tech Notes

title: Andrej Karpathy: Agentic Engineering replaces Vibe Coding
description: Andrej Karpathy declares that 'Vibe Coding is over' and introduces its successor: 'Agentic Engineering.' He emphasizes that the focus has shifted from casual experimentation to 'cruel and precise engineering' as AI approaches 99-100% code generation capability. Karpathy describes moving from 80% manual coding + autocomplete + 20% agents to the opposite, with AI now writing nearly all code. He predicts that those who master 'agentic engineering' will become 'super individuals' who reshape industry rules, while also warning about potential 'brain atrophy' alongside human capability evolution.
author: Andrej Karpathy

title: Anthropic Claude Max $200/month: 99% uptime claims vs January-February 2026 downtime
description: Hacker News discussion about Anthropic's Claude Max $200/month tier and their claimed 99% uptime. Users report significant downtime issues during January-February 2026, raising questions about reliability and service level agreements for enterprise AI coding tools. The conversation highlights the challenges of depending on cloud-based AI assistants for critical development workflows.
author: Hacker News community

title: Claude Code: connect to a local model when your quota runs out
description: Hacker News discussion about using local models when Claude quota runs out, comparing performance between local models and cloud-based services like Claude, Gemini, and Codex.
author: Hacker News community

title: Anthropic AI tool sparks selloff from software to broader market
description: Hacker News discussion about market reactions to Anthropic's AI tools, with debates about whether AI coding assistants are causing broader market shifts in the software industry. The conversation explores concerns about AI's impact on traditional software development roles and company valuations.
author: Hacker News community

title: Claude Opus 4.6 Finds 500+ High-Severity Security Flaws
description: The Hacker News reports that Claude Opus 4.6 discovered over 500 high-severity security vulnerabilities across various codebases, demonstrating AI's growing capability in automated security auditing and bug detection. This showcases how LLMs are becoming powerful tools for identifying critical security issues that human reviewers might miss.
author: The Hacker News

title: Introducing the Codex app
description: OpenAI released a new macOS app for their Codex coding agent. Key features include first-class support for Skills and Automations for running scheduled tasks. The app tracks state in SQLite and usage statistics show that since the launch of GPT-5.2-Codex in mid-December, overall Codex usage has doubled, with more than a million developers using Codex in the past month. Automations currently require the laptop to be powered on, with cloud-based automations coming soon.
author: Simon Willison

title: A Social Network for A.I. Bots Only. No Humans Allowed
description: Featured in the New York Times, this piece discusses OpenClaw and Moltbook - a social network for AI bots. Simon Willison was interviewed about how bots coaxed each other into talking like machines in sci-fi novels, noting that most of it is 'complete slop' but demonstrates how AI agents have become significantly more powerful. The article highlights how Moltbots created their own online forum and tools, showing the capabilities and limitations of current AI agent technology.
author: Simon Willison

title: TIL: Running OpenClaw in Docker
description: Technical notes on running OpenClaw using Docker on Mac, including setup commands, administrative tasks, Telegram bot configuration, and web UI access. The post provides practical insights into deploying and managing the OpenClaw AI agent system in a containerized environment.
author: Simon Willison

title: State of AI in 2026: LLMs, Coding, Scaling Laws, China, Agents, GPUs, AGI
description: Lex Fridman Podcast episode #490 featuring Nathan Lambert and Sebastian Raschka discussing the state of AI in 2026. Topics include the best AI for coding, state of LLMs, scaling laws, AI agents, GPU technology, AGI development, and AI competition with China. The episode provides a comprehensive overview of the current AI landscape and future directions.
author: Lex Fridman (with Nathan Lambert and Sebastian Raschka)

title: The unhinged world of tech in 2026
description: Fireship's satirical take on the tech world in 2026. The video highlights that LLMs have hit a plateau, GPT-5 is disappointing, and engineers haven't lost their jobs but instead have become 'code janitors' cleaning up messy AI-generated code. The video offers a humorous but insightful critique of AI's impact on software development, showing that instead of replacing programmers, AI has created new problems requiring human intervention.
author: Fireship

title: Andrej Karpathy on GPT-2 training cost reduction
description: Andrej Karpathy shared a remarkable stat: Originally in 2019, GPT-2 was trained on 32 TPU v3 chips for 168 hours at a cost of ~$43K. As of recent improvements in nanochat, he can now reach a higher CORE score in 3.04 hours (~$73) on a single 8XH100 node - a 600X cost reduction over 7 years, meaning the cost to train GPT-2 is falling approximately 2.5X every year.
author: Andrej Karpathy (quoted by Simon Willison)

title: Why AI coding agents feel powerful at first, then become frustrating
description: Hacker News discussion exploring the limitations of AI coding agents as projects scale - they feel powerful initially but become frustrating as codebases grow and complexity increases.
author: Hacker News community

title: Steve Yegge on Beads CLI design for AI agents
description: Steve Yegge discussed how Beads has evolved over 4 months of 'Desire Paths' design, developing a complex CLI with 100+ subcommands specifically designed for AI agents rather than humans. The approach involved making agent 'hallucinations real' by implementing whatever agents tried to do with Beads until nearly every guess by an agent is now correct.
author: Steve Yegge (quoted by Simon Willison)

title: Moltbook is the most interesting place on the internet right now
description: OpenClaw (formerly Clawdbot/Moltbot) is an open source digital personal assistant with over 114,000 stars on GitHub in just two months. The post explores the social network of AI bots, including prompt injection concerns, and how a bot created its own online forum called 'What I Learned Today.' The platform demonstrates both the power and risks of autonomous AI agents.
author: Simon Willison

title: AI as a programming tool for the arts
description: Chris Ashworth, creator of QLab (theater automation software), shares his 'Claude Opus moment' after using Claude Code to build a custom lighting design application in just a few days. Despite initial skepticism about AI, he acknowledges it's a career-changing moment. He emphasizes that AI can't make you a better programmer than you are - it can make bad programmers faster at making bad programs, or good programmers faster at making good programs. The key is understanding, directing, and editing the code.
author: Chris Ashworth (covered by Simon Willison)
